Skills Review

What we (should) already know

:)

Data Types

string integer float boolean list dictionary

There are a bunch of data types in Python, which you should already be familiar with. More data types do exist, but these are all the ones you should need.

Type Casting

string to integer
string to boolean

We can also convert between different data types. The most common conversion is turning a string into something more useful, like a number or a boolean. You most frequently need type conversion or "typecasting" when interpreting user input.

User Input

user_input = input("What is your name?")
Receiving user input from the command line is the most simple way to have your user interact with your program. Whenever we capture user input, we store it in a variable. Captured user input is always in string (text) format unless we specifically convert it to something else.

Lists and Dictionaries

names = [
  "Aroha"
  "Billy",
  "Clare"
]

scores = {
  "Alistair": 30,
  "Beyonce": 70,
  "Clive": 50
}
We can also group data together in a few different ways. For an ordered group of values, we can use a list. For an unordered group of values, accessible by name, we an use a dictionary.

Loops

Do the same thing over…
and over… and over…

Loops let us run the same piece of code over and over until a condition is met. Some common conditions would be: - A counter has reached a given limit - Every item in a list has been processed - A boolean value is no longer true

Conditionals

if, elif, else

Conditionals are more commonly known as "if statements", and can be used to only run a piece of code if a given condition evaluates to "true".

Challenge:
Debug the Burger Builder

Open up burgerbuilder.py and make it work better:

  1. All unchanging values should be stored in constants.
  2. The app should apologise if it doesn’t have a requested filling.
  3. The app should be able to collect as many orders as needed.
